abstract.text: Obtains the status of a CMS message’s signature.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A number indicating which signer to examine. Signer index numbers start with 0. Use the
function to determine the total number of signers for a message.
The trust policy or policies to be used to verify the signer’s certificate. You can specify either a single
instances. For more information about policy objects, see
to cause the decoder to call the
instance created for the evaluation of the signer certificate. Set to
if you intend to call the
parameter, on return this parameter indicates the status of the signature. See
if you don’t want a value returned.
On return this parameter points to a
parameter, this is the trust instance that was used to verify the signer’s certificate. If you specified
if you do not want this instance returned. You must use the
function to free this reference when you are finished using it.
parameter, on return this parameter indicates the result of the certificate verification.  Pass in
if you don’t want a value returned.
Some of the most common results returned in this parameter include:
The certificate was verified through the certificate chain to a self-signed root certificate that was present in the message, but that root certificate is not a known, trusted root certificate.
The certificate could not be verified back to a root certificate.
Trust could not be established according to the specified trust policy.
The signer’s leaf certificate was not valid.
A certificate in the chain was expired at the time of verification.
A certificate in the chain was not yet valid at the time of verification.
indicates only that the function completed successfully; it does not indicate that the signature is verified or the certificates are valid. See the
parameters for the verification and certificate validation results.
You cannot call this function until after you have called the
function. Although the message has been fully decoded when the
function returns with no error, the signature can’t be validated or certificates verified until this function is called.
A CMS message can be signed by multiple signers; this function returns the status associated with one signer as specified by the
parameter, no evaluation of the signer certificate can occur.

abstract.text: Releases a Core Foundation object.
A reference to an immutable array object.
A false value.
A true value.
Secure the data your app manages, and control access to your app.
An opaque reference to a CMS decoder object.
Obtains the status of a CMS message’s signature.
Creates a CMSDecoder reference.
Indicates that there is no more data to decode.
Obtains the number of signers of a message.
The constants that indicate the status of the signature and signer information in a signed message.
An object that represents a trust policy.
An object used to evaluate trust.
Evaluates trust for the specified certificate and policies.
No error.
Obtain policies for establishing trust.
Evaluate result codes common to many Security framework functions.
An untyped "generic" reference to any Core Foundation object.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
A signed integer value type.
A pointer for accessing and manipulating data of a specific type.
